comment_text.mn147:1.4: Five perceptions that ripen in freedom are taught at DN 33:2.1.139, but apart from that we do not encounter this idea in the discourses. | In SN 18.1–5, Rāhula requests a teaching so he can go on retreat. The teachings given there can be compared with the parallel, which says the Buddha first told Rāhula to teach the five aggregates, the six sense-spheres, and conditionality, and then to go on retreat and meditate on the same teachings (SA 200 at T ii 51a23). Only then did the Buddha consider him ready.
comment_text.mn147:1.8: The sitting cloth was a standard requisite of monastics (Bu Pc 89). Regularly featured in the texts of the Sarvāstivāda schools, it is rarely mentioned in the Pali suttas (but see DN 16:3.1.3).
comment_text.mn147:2.1: The presence of a thousand deities, which is unique to this discourse, is not mentioned in the Chinese parallel, and is obviously a later addition.

root_text.mn147:9.6: manasmiṁ nibbindati, dhammesu nibbindati, manoviññāṇe nibbindati, manosamphasse nibbindati, yamidaṁ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedanāgataṁ saññāgataṁ saṅkhāragataṁ viññāṇagataṁ tasmimpi nibbindati.
root_text.mn147:9.7: Nibbindaṁ virajjati, virāgā vimuccati. Vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn147:9.8: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
root_text.mn147:9.10: Attamano āyasmā rāhulo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.
root_text.mn147:9.11: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṁ bhaññamāne āyasmato rāhulassa anupādāya āsavehi cittaṁ vimucci.
root_text.mn147:9.12: Tāsañca anekānaṁ devatāsahassānaṁ virajaṁ vītamalaṁ dhammacakkhuṁ udapādi:

translation_text.mn147:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn147:1.3: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
translation_text.mn147:1.4: “The qualities that ripen in freedom have ripened in Rāhula.
translation_text.mn147:1.5: Why don’t I lead him further to the ending of defilements?”
translation_text.mn147:1.6: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
translation_text.mn147:1.7: Then, after the meal, on his return from almsround, he addressed Venerable Rāhula,
translation_text.mn147:1.9: Let’s go to the Dark Forest for the day’s meditation.”
translation_text.mn147:1.10: “Yes, sir,” replied Rāhula. Taking his sitting cloth he followed behind the Buddha.
translation_text.mn147:2.1: Now at that time many thousands of deities followed the Buddha, thinking,
translation_text.mn147:2.2: “Today the Buddha will lead Rāhula further to the ending of defilements!”
translation_text.mn147:2.3: Then the Buddha plunged deep into the Dark Forest and sat at the root of a tree on the seat spread out.
translation_text.mn147:2.4: Rāhula bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.

translation_text.mn147:9.1: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. And they grow disillusioned with anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises dependent on eye contact.
translation_text.mn147:9.2: They grow disillusioned with the ear …
translation_text.mn147:9.6: mind, ideas, mind consciousness, and mind contact. And they grow disillusioned with anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises dependent on mind contact.
translation_text.mn147:9.7: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
translation_text.mn147:9.8: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”
translation_text.mn147:9.9: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn147:9.10: Satisfied, Venerable Rāhula approved what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn147:9.11: And while this discourse was being spoken, Rāhula’s mind was freed from defilements by not grasping.
translation_text.mn147:9.12: And the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in those thousands of deities:
translation_text.mn147:9.13: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”
